query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 Ricorditi, lettor, se mai ne l’alpe 2 ti colse nebbia per la qual vedessi 3 non altrimenti che per pelle talpe,
query.error: **English:** 1 Remember, reader, if ever in the Alps 2 a fog caught you through which you saw 3 no otherwise than through a mole's skin,
query.result: 1 Gemunað ðu, rædend, gif ðu on eorðan æfre 2 mist oferwreah ðe on muntes hliðe, 3 ðæt ðu ne mihtest geseon ðurh ða sweartan wolcnu,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
4 come, quando i vapori umidi e spessi 5 a diradar cominciansi, la spera 6 del sol debilemente entra per essi;
query.error: **English:** 4 how, when the moist and thick vapors 5 begin to thin out, the sphere 6 of the sun enters through them feebly;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 e fia la tua imagine leggera 8 in giugnere a veder com’ io rividi 9 lo sole in pria, che già nel corcar era.
query.error: **English:** 7 and your light image will be 8 in reaching to see how I saw again 9 the sun, which was already setting.
query.result: 7 and ðin leoht mod ðonne bið 8 on ðam ðe ðu gesihst hu ic eft geseah 9 ða sunnan on morgen, ða heo ær on æfen wæs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 Sì, pareggiando i miei co’ passi fidi 11 del mio maestro, usci’ fuor di tal nube 12 ai raggi morti già ne’ bassi lidi.
query.error: **English:** 10 Yes, by matching my faithful steps 11 with those of my master, I emerged from that cloud 12 to the rays that were already dead on the low shores.
query.result: 10 Swa, efenlætende mine treowan stapas 11 ðæs ðe me fore wæs, ða ic of ðam wudu com 12 on ða openan leohte ðær ða deadan liðað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 O imaginativa che ne rube 14 talvolta sì di fuor, ch’om non s’accorge 15 perché dintorno suonin mille tube,
query.error: **English:** 13 O imagination, that sometimes 14 so enraptures us from without, 15 that we perceive not though a thousand trumpets
query.result: 13 Eala ðu geþoht ðe oft us onwæcð 14 utanweardlice ðæt we ne gemunað 15 ðeah ðusend horn blawen beon,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 chi move te, se ’l senso non ti porge? 17 Moveti lume che nel ciel s’informa, 18 per sé o per voler che giù lo scorge.
query.error: **English:** 16 sound around us, 17 what moves you, if the senses do not bring it to you? 18 You are moved by light that is formed in heaven,
query.result: 16 hwæt styreð ðe, gif ðin geþoht ne bið? 17 Styreð ðe ðæt leoht ðe on heofonum bið geworht, 18 ðurh hine sylfne oððe ðurh ðone willan ðe hine niðer senðeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 De l’empiezza di lei che mutò forma 20 ne l’uccel ch’a cantar più si diletta, 21 ne l’imagine mia apparve l’orma;
query.error: **English:** 19 Of the wickedness of her who changed form 20 into the bird that takes most delight in singing, 21 the trace appeared in my mind;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 e qui fu la mia mente sì ristretta 23 dentro da sé, che di fuor non venìa 24 cosa che fosse allor da lei ricetta.
query.error: **English:** 22 and here my mind was so constricted 23 within itself that nothing from outside 24 came that was then received by it.
query.result: 22 and ðær wæs min mod swa gedrefed 23 innanweardne ðæt ðær bute ne com 24 ðing ðæt ða ðurh ða ðær onfangen wære.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Poi piovve dentro a l’alta fantasia 26 un crucifisso, dispettoso e fero 27 ne la sua vista, e cotal si moria;
query.error: **English:** 25 Then rained down into the lofty fantasy 26 a crucifix, disdainful and fierce 27 in its appearance, and thus he died;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 intorno ad esso era il grande Assüero, 29 Estèr sua sposa e ’l giusto Mardoceo, 30 che fu al dire e al far così intero.
query.error: **English:** 28 around it was the great Ahasuerus, 29 Esther his wife, and the just Mordecai, 30 who was so steadfast in word and deed.
query.result: 28 ymbe ðæt wæron ða mæran Assuerus, 29 Esther his bryd and se rihtwisa Mardocheus, 30 se wæs on spræce and on dædum swiðe trum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 E come questa imagine rompeo 32 sé per sé stessa, a guisa d’una bulla 33 cui manca l’acqua sotto qual si feo,
query.error: **English:** 31 And as this image bursts 32 by itself, like a bubble 33 that lacks the water beneath which it was created,
query.result: 31 And swa swa ðeos anlicnes tobærst 32 ðurh hi sylfe, gelic snædes bleðre 33 ðære wætre ateorigð under ðære heo gewearð,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 surse in mia visïone una fanciulla 35 piangendo forte, e dicea: «O regina, 36 perché per ira hai voluto esser nulla?
query.error: **English:** 34 a young woman appeared in my vision, 35 weeping loudly, and saying: "O queen, 36 why have you wished to be nothing out of anger?
query.result: 34 ða aras on ðære gesyhðe me fæmne 35 wepende swiðe, and cwæð: "Eala, ðu cwén, 36 for hwon ðu ðurh yrre woldest beon nawiht?

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 Ancisa t’hai per non perder Lavina; 38 or m’hai perduta! Io son essa che lutto, 39 madre, a la tua pria ch’a l’altrui ruina».
query.error: **English:** 37 You have killed yourself so as not to lose Lavinia; 38 now you have lost me! I am the one who grieves, 39 mother, for your ruin before anyone else's."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 Come si frange il sonno ove di butto 41 nova luce percuote il viso chiuso, 42 che fratto guizza pria che muoia tutto;
query.error: **English:** 40 As sleep is broken when a sudden 41 new light strikes the closed eyes, 42 which, shattered, flicker before they die completely;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 così l’imaginar mio cadde giuso 44 tosto che lume il volto mi percosse, 45 maggior assai che quel ch’è in nostro uso.
query.error: **English:** 43 so my imagination fell down 44 as soon as a light struck my face, 45 much greater than that which we are accustomed to.
query.result: 43 swa min mod geleaf ða hit 44 ða ðæt leoht on ðæt nebwe scân, 45 micle ma þonne ænig monn oðer.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 I’ mi volgea per veder ov’ io fosse, 47 quando una voce disse «Qui si monta», 48 che da ogne altro intento mi rimosse;
query.error: **English:** 46 I turned to see where I was, 47 when a voice said, "Here one ascends," 48 which drew me away from every other thought;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 e fece la mia voglia tanto pronta 50 di riguardar chi era che parlava, 51 che mai non posa, se non si raffronta.
query.error: **English:** 49 and it made my desire so keen 50 to look at the one who was speaking, 51 that I never rest until I confront him.
query.result: 49 and min mod geworhte ða swiðe geornful 50 ðæs ðe ic ðone gesawe ðe ðær spræc, 51 ðæt ic næfre geswac ær ic ðone gesohte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 Ma come al sol che nostra vista grava 53 e per soverchio sua figura vela, 54 così la mia virtù quivi mancava.
query.error: **English:** 52 But as the sun, which weighs upon our sight, 53 and veils its form with its own excess, 54 so my strength failed me there.
query.result: 52 Ac swa swa ðære sunnan ðe ure gesihðe hreosað 53 and ðurh ðæs ofermægnes hire ansyn hyleð, 54 swa min mægen ðær meahte lease.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 «Questo è divino spirito, che ne la 56 via da ir sù ne drizza sanza prego, 57 e col suo lume sé medesmo cela.
query.error: **English:** 55 "This is a divine spirit, who guides us 56 on the path to ascend without being asked, 57 and with his light conceals himself."
query.result: 55 "Þis is godcund gast, se ðe on stige 56 ne læt ðurh bede bidan, 57 and mid his leohte hine sylfne hylt."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 Sì fa con noi, come l’uom si fa sego; 59 ché quale aspetta prego e l’uopo vede, 60 malignamente già si mette al nego.
query.error: **English:** 58 He does with us as a man does with himself; 59 for he who waits for a request and sees the need, 60 malignantly already sets himself to deny it.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Or accordiamo a tanto invito il piede; 62 procacciam di salir pria che s’abbui, 63 ché poi non si poria, se ’l dì non riede».
query.error: **English:** 61 Now let us yield our feet to such invitation; 62 let us strive to climb before it gets dark, 63 for then it would not be possible, if the day does not return.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 Così disse il mio duca, e io con lui 65 volgemmo i nostri passi ad una scala; 66 e tosto ch’io al primo grado fui,
query.error: **English:** 64 Thus spoke my guide, and I with him 65 turned our steps to a stairway; 66 and as soon as I was on the first step,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 senti’mi presso quasi un muover d’ala 68 e ventarmi nel viso e dir: ‘Beati 69 pacifici, che son sanz’ ira mala!’.
query.error: **English:** 67 I felt near me almost a movement of wings 68 and a wind blowing on my face and saying: ‘Blessed 69 are the peacemakers, who are without evil wrath!’.
query.result: 67 ic gehyrde mé néh ðær swilce hweorfunʒe fidera 68 and wind mé wæfian on ðæm wlite and cweðan: ‘Eadige 69 sibsumiende, ðe sind bútan yfelum yrre!’.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 Già eran sovra noi tanto levati 71 li ultimi raggi che la notte segue, 72 che le stelle apparivan da più lati.
query.error: **English:** 70 Now the last rays which the night follows 71 were already so high above us, 72 that the stars were appearing on many sides.
query.result: 70 Nu wæron ða ufanweardestan 71 ðara læstan leoma ðe ða niht tyhð, 72 ðæt ða steorran on staðelum stodon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 ‘O virtù mia, perché sì ti dilegue?’, 74 fra me stesso dicea, ché mi sentiva 75 la possa de le gambe posta in triegue.
query.error: **English:** 73 "O my strength, why do you desert me so?", 74 I said to myself, for I felt 75 the power of my legs put in a truce.
query.result: 73 "Eala min mægen, hwi ðu me ðus forlætest?", 74 cwæð ic to me sylfum, ða ic me sylfa funde 75 ðone cræft mīnra fōta on slæpe setne.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 Noi eravam dove più non saliva 77 la scala sù, ed eravamo affissi, 78 pur come nave ch’a la piaggia arriva.
query.error: **English:** 76 We were where the stairs no longer ascended, 77 and we were fixed, 78 just like a ship that arrives at the shore.
query.result: 76 We wæron ðær ðær ða stæger ne stigon 77 uppan, and we wæron afæste, 78 swilce scip ðæt to ðære sæ cyrreð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 E io attesi un poco, s’io udissi 80 alcuna cosa nel novo girone; 81 poi mi volsi al maestro mio, e dissi:
query.error: **English:** 79 And I waited a little, to see if I heard 80 anything in the new circle; 81 then I turned to my master and said:

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 «Dolce mio padre, dì, quale offensione 83 si purga qui nel giro dove semo? 84 Se i piè si stanno, non stea tuo sermone».
query.error: **English:** 82 "My sweet father, tell me, what offense 83 is purged here in the circle where we are? 84 If our feet are standing still, let not your speech be so."
query.result: 82 "Leof fæder mín, sege me, hwylc gescyld 83 bið geclænsod hér on ðam ymbhwyrfe ðær we synd? 84 Gif ða fét standað, ne stande ðín spræc."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Ed elli a me: «L’amor del bene, scemo 86 del suo dover, quiritta si ristora; 87 qui si ribatte il mal tardato remo.
query.error: **English:** 85 And he to me: "The love of good, bereft 86 of its duty, is here restored; 87 here the oar, delayed too long, is beaten again.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 Ma perché più aperto intendi ancora, 89 volgi la mente a me, e prenderai 90 alcun buon frutto di nostra dimora».
query.error: **English:** 88 But so that you may understand more clearly, 89 turn your mind to me, and you will receive 90 some good fruit from our conversation.
query.result: 88 Ac ðæt ðu georne gehyrðe, 89 wende ðinne hyge to me, and ðu gepenceð 90 sumne godne wæstm of ure spræce.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 «Né creator né creatura mai», 92 cominciò el, «figliuol, fu sanza amore, 93 o naturale o d’animo; e tu ’l sai.
query.error: **English:** 91 "Neither creator nor creature ever," 92 he began, "my son, was without love, 93 either natural or of the mind; and you know it.
query.result: 91 "Ne gesceaft ne gesceap næfre," 92 ongan he, "min sunu, wæs butan lufe, 93 oððe gecyndelic oððe on mode; ðu ðæt wast.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 Lo naturale è sempre sanza errore, 95 ma l’altro puote errar per malo obietto 96 o per troppo o per poco di vigore.
query.error: **English:** 94 The natural is always without error, 95 but the other can err because of a bad object 96 or because of too much or too little vigor.
query.result: 94 Þæt gecynde is simle butan gedwylde, 95 ac þæt oðer mæg gedwolan for yfelum andgite 96 oððe for to mycclum oððe for to lytlum mægene.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 Mentre ch’elli è nel primo ben diretto, 98 e ne’ secondi sé stesso misura, 99 esser non può cagion di mal diletto;
query.error: **English:** 97 While he is rightly directed in the first good, 98 and in the second measures himself, 99 he cannot be the cause of evil delight;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 ma quando al mal si torce, o con più cura 101 o con men che non dee corre nel bene, 102 contra ’l fattore adovra sua fattura.
query.error: **English:** 100 but when he turns to evil, either with more care 101 or with less than he should run in the good, 102 he uses his creation against the creator.
query.result: 100 ac ðonne he to ðæm yfle gewent, oððe mid mare geornfulnesse 101 oððe mid læsse ðonne he sceolde on ðæm godan rinnan, 102 ðonne wyrcð he his geworht wið ðone wyrhta.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Quinci comprender puoi ch’esser convene 104 amor sementa in voi d’ogne virtute 105 e d’ogne operazion che merta pene.
query.error: **English:** 103 From this you can understand that love must be 104 the seed in you of every virtue 105 and of every operation that merits reward.
query.result: 103 Heonon ðu meaht ongitan ðæt hit gelimpan sceal 104 ðæt lufu sæweð on eow ælce geðeaw 105 and ælces weorces ðe mede sceal habban.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 Or, perché mai non può da la salute 107 amor del suo subietto volger viso, 108 da l’odio proprio son le cose tute;
query.error: **English:** 106 Now, why can love of its subject never turn 107 its face away from salvation, 108 all things are from their own hatred;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 e perché intender non si può diviso, 110 e per sé stante, alcuno esser dal primo, 111 da quello odiare ogne effetto è deciso.
query.error: **English:** 109 and why it cannot be understood as divided, 110 and standing by itself, any being from the first, 111 from that to hate every effect is decided.
query.result: 109 and hwi hit ne mæg beon ongieten todæled, 110 and ðurh hit self standende, ænig ðing of ðam forman, 111 of ðam to hatianne ælc endebyrdnis is gedon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Resta, se dividendo bene stimo, 113 che ’l mal che s’ama è del prossimo; ed esso 114 amor nasce in tre modi in vostro limo.
query.error: **English:** 112 It remains, if I judge correctly by dividing [things], 113 that the evil that is loved is that of one's neighbor; and this 114 love is born in three ways in your clay.
query.result: 112 Hit wunað, gif ic wel deme ðurh todælen, 113 ðæt ðæt yfel ðe man lufað is his nehstan; and hit 114 bið on ðrim wisum acenned on eowrum lame.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 È chi, per esser suo vicin soppresso, 116 spera eccellenza, e sol per questo brama 117 ch’el sia di sua grandezza in basso messo;
query.error: **English:** 115 And he who, because his neighbor is more successful, 116 hopes for his downfall, and desires only 117 that he be brought low from his greatness;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 è chi podere, grazia, onore e fama 119 teme di perder perch’ altri sormonti, 120 onde s’attrista sì che ’l contrario ama;
query.error: **English:** 118 and he who fears to lose power, favor, honor, and fame 119 because others surpass him, 120 so that he becomes so distressed that he desires the opposite;
query.result: 118 and se ðe ondræt ðæt he forleose 119 weald and wurðmynt and wuldor and lof, 120 ðurh ðæt ðe oðre hine oferstígað,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 ed è chi per ingiuria par ch’aonti, 122 sì che si fa de la vendetta ghiotto, 123 e tal convien che ’l male altrui impronti.
query.error: **English:** 121 and he who feels wronged and offended, 122 so that he becomes greedy for revenge, 123 and it is necessary for him to inflict harm on others.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Questo triforme amor qua giù di sotto 125 si piange: or vo’ che tu de l’altro intende, 126 che corre al ben con ordine corrotto.
query.error: **English:** 124 This threefold love is lamented down here below: 125 now I want you to understand about the other kind, 126 which runs to good with a corrupted order.
query.result: 124 Þeos ðreo-fealde lufu her niðe 125 bið beweopad: nu ic wille ðæt ðu ðæs oðres ongiete, 126 ðe to ðam gode mid gedrefeledum bigangeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Ciascun confusamente un bene apprende 128 nel qual si queti l’animo, e disira; 129 per che di giugner lui ciascun contende.
query.error: **English:** 127 Each one confusedly apprehends a good 128 in which the soul finds peace and desires; 129 therefore each one strives to attain it.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 Se lento amore a lui veder vi tira 131 o a lui acquistar, questa cornice, 132 dopo giusto penter, ve ne martira.
query.error: **English:** 130 If slow love draws you to see him 131 or to acquire him, this cornice, 132 after just repentance, torments you.
query.result: 130 Gif ðin slæwe lufu ðe tihð to ðæs monnes gesyhðe 131 oððe to ðæs monnes geearnunge, ðeos ymbhwyrft, 132 æfter rihtre dædbote, ðe ðrægeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 Altro ben è che non fa l’uom felice; 134 non è felicità, non è la buona 135 essenza, d’ogne ben frutto e radice.
query.error: **English:** 133 There is another good that makes man happy; 134 it is not happiness, it is not the good 135 essence, the fruit and root of every good.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
136 L’amor ch’ad esso troppo s’abbandona, 137 di sovr’ a noi si piange per tre cerchi; 138 ma come tripartito si ragiona,
query.error: **English:** 136 Love that abandons itself too much to it, 137 is lamented above us for three circles; 138 but how it is divided into three,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 tacciolo, acciò che tu per te ne cerchi».
query.error: **English:** 139 I am silent, so that you may search for it yourself."
query.result: 139 ðæt ic ðæs swige, ðæt ðu ðæt ðe self secge."
